Listen every one, I ordered moto x play and moto G turbo together (x play for me and turbo for my sister). 
Inspite of given better specs in x play, the performance in x play is far behind when compared to g turbo. 
X play lags a lot without even installing any single app, whereas G turbo on the other hand is buttery smooth even after loading tons of apps. 
Highly disappointed after buying moto.

The only big difference in specs that affects the performance between the Moto X play and Moto G Turbo is the Moto X plays big screen and the resolution. Moto G Turbo has a 5 inch 720p screen while X play has a 5.5 inch 1080p. Other than that the processor and the ram are identical. Maybe that is why the G Turbo feels more fluid. Having said that, I have been using X play for over a month and haven't noticed any lags or stutters that frequently. Also given the bigger battery, better camera and better screen, I feel X play has more pros over the G Turbo. 
P.S: From what I have heard about the Marshmallow update for X play, it improves the performance by a lot. So fingers crossed.
Posted via Moto X Play

Hey everyone, just wanted to throw my two cents into the pool. I had very little lag throughout various ui interactions before marshmallow, however since updating to m I have had almost zero issues. I tried the few interaction mention in the o.p. and had non of those stutters. Don't know if I've been lucky but I'll thank the tech gods for it. And hope this post doesn't jinx it.
Posted via the Android Central App

Just want to chime in on Dekesask's comment - I also had almost no lag when I first turned this phone on with 5.1.1. Even after installing all of my apps and whatnot, there was almost zero lag (except when 45 apps were installing and I was multitasking...even then, hardly noticeable). Keep in mind, I'm coming from an iPhone 5S which is still relatively smooth. Comparatively, I'm finding my X Play to run MUCH better than the iPhone has been in the last few months. 
Yesterday I updated to Marshmallow and I can absolutely say without a doubt that this thing flies on 6.0. Even with the GNL. On top of that, I'm running Nova Launcher Prime and it is buttery smooth. In case anyone is worried about this phone being bogged down, I'd say that Moto probably focused on optimizing 6.0 software instead of 5.1.1. Hopefully others have found similar results! 
All in all, I'm in absolute love with this phone. Finally found the one that will make me kick my iOS addiction for good 
EDIT: I should specify, it's important to do a factory reset after doing an OTA Marshmallow update. My experiences are based on that, so YMMV.

title: All cores disabled. How is my phone even running?

thread.text:
Hi everyone, I bought my moto x play last week and I'm experiencing some lag and crashing issues. I ran the antutu benchmark and got a very low score compared to other people's (21k). Trying to find out what's wrong, I noticed Antutu was saying my cpu frequency is 36 MHz, which is bizarre. To check my CPU specs, I downloaded cpu-z and it's now saying all 8 CPU cores are stopped. How is it even possible? 
I also downloaded other CPU analysis softwares and all say the same: the 8 cores are either disabled or sleeping.
Thanks in advance for any answer.

Hi Tiago, welcome to the forums! That's weird, you shouldn't be having any crash with your new phone and the Untutu benchmarks should show 32 to 35k at least. Being a brand new phone I would try a factory reset just to make sure you didn't get a faulty device. Have you downloaded any app that could be the cause of those performance problems?

Try something Tiago. Boot your phone in safe mode and check if the problem persists. To do so press & hold on the power button, press & hold on the Power Off option and then select safe mode.

God, I hate this, but I don't think I have another choice, I'll have to go back to my Nexus 4 and try to convince Motorola to give me a new Moto X Play.
I also tried booting it in safe mode, same problem. Thanks for the help anyway.

title: Can't browse micro sd storage via USB after 6.0 upgrade (moto x play)

thread.text:
Long time iphone user, recently switched to a moto x play a few weeks ago. This is probably a stupid question, but I can't seem to figure it out.
My moto x play has 16gb of internal storage. I've added a 64gb microsd card. The phone recognizes it fine, and I'm able to use it as expected.
When I plug my phone in to my computer, and put it in "MTP" mode, I can see two directories. One is called "internal storage" and the other is called "sandisk sd card"
If I click on the internal storage, I can see all the subdirectories, I can add and remove files as you'd expect.
If I click on the "sandisk sd card" I can see that it has 49gb of 59.4gb free... But I can't see any directories, and I can't create any files/directories. There's several gigs of music, but I can't see it from my pc.
If I take the microsd card out, put it in an sd adapter and slide it in to my computer, then I can view/edit/modify/etc files to my hearts content.
I'm pretty sure prior to upgrading to Marshmallow I was able to to just drag and drop music on to the sd storage without having to take it out of the phone first.
I did not choose to have the sd card absorbed as part of the internal storage during the 6.0 upgrade. The internal and SD storage still appear separate.
I feel like this is something I should be able to do pretty easily, and I must just be missing something basic.
Any help is appreciated.
I'm running windows10 if that makes a difference. I have tried several different cables, and several different usb ports on my computer.
**edit
I think it's resolved. In case anyone comes across a similar problem, it seemed to be resolved by formatting the sd card, choosing to absorb it as internal storage, then formatting again as portable. Sorry for the noise.

I had to do the same. Kind of a pain for those who don't want to format it. I'm using Linux so I don't think it's a specific OS, just Marshmallow.
Posted via my Moto X Play

title: Why does Google Play services drain my batter?

thread.text:
Hi everyone,
i have moto x play since monday, and i have a big battery problem.
In fact, google play service drain my batterie. A the end of the day, i have 40% of battery with something like 20% of google play services in my battery stats.
I took this phone for the autonomy, it's really better than i had before, but google play services
is very anoying.
Any idea ?
Oh and sorry for my english, i'm french :)

Google services (without the play) is always at the top of my battery usage list. I haven't found a way to reduce it. 
You could try uninstalling updates for Google play services then re-update to the latest version, that might help. 
First go to security/device administrators in settings and untick android device manager. Then go to apps, find Google play services and uninstall updates. 
I would then reboot. Then when prompted (you'll get warnings about play services not being up to date) follow the notification and update to the latest version. The tick android decide manager in device administrators. 
That might help.
Posted via the Android Central App

Can someone do a antutu test eith cm

Which skin are you using?
Posted via moto x play

It's because of a common bug in Android Lolipop: Mobile Radio Active
It's a drain that occurs when not connected to a Wi-Fi network, it keeps apps looking for a connecting when closed.
I got the same problems, but it doesn't drain on Wi-Fi (3-4 days standby) but on 3g / LTE it drains the battery quite fast (1,5
In Android 6.0 Marshmallow this should be fixed. Just google on "Mobile Radio Active Bug"

Check if Google keyboard had sync turned on, I did and Google services was always at the top of battery usage and I could not get beyond 4 hours of screen on time, now I'm on 4 hours and 48% battery left. It finally worked
Still struggling with this drain, so annoying.

My understanding is its a lollipop bug where mobile data drains too much battery. I find if I stay on WiFi then Google services hardly shows up but away from WiFi its always the top of the list. My hope is that itll be better with MM!
Posted via the Android Central App

If you restrict background data on Google Services in the data screen, this issue goes away. 
However, a new issue seems to crop up. Android OS will now use more power due to "mobile radio active" instead. It uses more than it would normally, but I have found its still less than what Google Services would have used before.
Posted via the Android Central App
I tried this today and it certainly did help my drain. However, it also made inbox and Hangouts go very wonky. Had to enable it again.

Yeah it's a real problem in Lollipop. I can tell you it is fixed in the Marshmallow update. My battery is lasting beautifully on MM now. 
This is off charge at 5:30 Am and its now 12:30pm. So that's pretty decent in my books, and I have had music streaming over Bluetooth since about 8am. Screen on 45 mins.

replies.text: Android version you're running on?

5.1.1
Posted via the Android Central App

thread.text:
Welcome to Android Central! Try booting into Safe Mode, which temporarily disables all 3rd party apps. https://motorola-global-portal.custh...kw/safe%20mode
If the problem disappears in Safe Mode, then something you installed is causing the problem. You may have to uninstall apps one by one until the problem disappears. If the problem persists in Safe Mode, then it's more likely to be a hardware or firmware problem.

replies.text: He mentioned he tried Factory reset.. How would safe mode help?

First, the OP talked about restoring the Calendar app to its factory version, not doing a full factory data reset.
Second, if you factory reset and then sign back into the phone, Google will usually restore a lot of your data, including automatically reinstalling apps from Google Play Store. So unless you went immediately to the Google Play Store after finishing the Setup Wizard to stop any app from automatically installing, then you might not be starting with a clean slate--and therefore a 3rd party app might still cause problems.
Agreed. My bad. I didn't give proper attention thinking about Factory Reset.

title: Any regrets?

thread.text:
Now we've all had the phone for weeks or even months, how is everyone feeling about it?
have to admit I keep eyeing up the nexus 5x as I am really disappointed by the performance issues and perhaps I do regret getting it. I dusted off my old nexus 5 and installed marshmallow and it runs a hundred times better than the x play. Yes its on newer software but it's a 2 year old phone! 
Also find is disappointing how little I've heard mentioned about marshmallow for the play. Feel a bit like moto aren't treating it as a priority somehow which I guess it isn't given that it didn't get a global release. 
I do really like the battery and screen size of the play so hopefully marshmallow will sort it out but somewhat disappointed at this time...
Posted via the Android Central App

I think the Play runs fine. I'm also tempted to get the 5x, as the 5 was possibly my favorite phone of all time. The thing that stops me, is once I have the nexus 5x for a few weeks and the novelty of having a new phone wears off, I'm sure I would quickly realize I'm getting nothing new out of it that I didn't already have on the X Play (apart from a fingerprint scanner).
They both run stock android (but the Play has a few more features), both have a 1080p screen, X Play has better battery life. I just can't think of anything the 5x can offer me over the play? Sure the 5x probably has better performance, but it would be ever so slightly. I saw a side by side video of the two phones, of someone comparing the two phones opening apps, multitasking, booting etc, and the difference was so small.

I don't have any regrets at all. Been using the X Play for almost three months and never had a problem. Recent updates have improved performance in apps like Play Store or Now launcher. There are still a couple of animation stutters here and there but in general the performance is good. 
Before buying this phone I considered waiting for the 5X and now I'm sure I made the right decision. The X Play suits my needs better that the 5X would. So, I'm quite happy so far. 
There are no leaks of soak test for this phone but I'm not so worried. I think we'll get Marshmallow still this year.

Ya moto g 2014 soak test leaked but no sign of moto x play soak test
Posted via the Android Central App

None whatsoever. This phone covers the weaknesses of my N5 and my Moto X 2014, which were an extremely reduced battery performance AND a display which under direct sunlight could not be viewed.
And yes I miss the responsiveness, complete lack of stutter, color reproduction and IR sensor of my previous phones but I completely forget what I miss at the end of the day where I still have more than 60% of battery left...
It seems to me that the ideal pure or near pure Android phone has not been built yet. And my X play is the nearest solution available today...

Had mine 3 days and no regrets. I had nexus 5x and while it is excellent on marshmallow it just feels to cheap and plastic and big for a 5.2" screen. I only paid £200 for the play on recent Amazon deal and for that price you won't get any better in my opinion. 
Great screen, although plastic great build, good front facing mono speaker, good camera, but best thing about this phone is battery life. My first cycle was 1 day 20 hours with 5hrs 30mins screen time. 
There is the odd animation stutter but it's rare, I was worried about the 615 soc but it's good on this phone, apps open fast multitasking is fast. I'm just not sure if marshmallow will smooth everything out or its limited by the 615. But for the price the play is excellent.

title: Bricked my phone, how can I fix it?

thread.text:
I am not able to start my phone .My phone stuck at boot loader unlock waring i have tried to instal CM12.1 Rom with TWRP but with this method
Download the CM12.1 ROM from the download section. Also download either the listed Google Apps or get your preferred Gapps.
Now transfer the two zip files into your device’s internal storage. Place the zip file where you can easily locate it.
Now reboot into Custom Recovery (like TWRP). To boot into TWRP, press and hold volume down and power keys at the same time.
It is highly recommended that you perform a nandroid backup. To backup your ROM, tap on backup option in TWRP and select the following elements: System, Data, Boot, Recovery, EFS and swipe right where appropriate, to backup.
After performing the ROM backup, return to the TWRP main menu and tap the Wipe button and select Advanced Wipe. Then select Dalvik Cache, System, Data, and Cache. Now swipe right to confirm.
Go back to the TWRP main menu or home screen again and tap on Install option. Navigate to the ROM file and select it.
Swipe the confirmation button to proceed with installation. The ROM will be installed. (at here i am receiving Errors)
Now again return to home in the TWRP and tap on Install option. Navigate to the Google apps zip file and select it. (also i am not able to install gapps)
Swipe the confirmation button to proceed with installation..
Once installed, reboot to system.
i am still receiving some issues i have attached print screen for your review can please let me know what i am doing wrong ???

Interesting! I've found two other people so far with the same issues; one of them is even on a Moto X Pure.

Ok will gather the information for you soon.

I have same issue as well.
I have an LG G watch and moto x play.
Anyone solved this?

Same issue with my new Moto X Play (no carrier brand or something).
All worked fine before with my Moto360 and my Nexus 5 but since the MotoXPlay it does not keep the notifications at the phone silence.
I would imagine it has something to do with Motorola's Apps (Moto Assist) but did not test it out yet.

OK, just took another look into it.
Every time the screen is locked the "muted by Android Wear" setting is gone from the volume area.
What is special there? Motorola has it's own lock screen notifications but you can turn this off (Notifications / Choose a display).
I just switched away from "Moto Display" to one of the alternatives which both worked for me ("Ambient Display" or "None").
Now when I lock the screen and unlock it again, the "muted by Android Wear" stays (for now at least).
It also worked with receiving a message while the screen was locked for me.
Maybe worth a try...

thread.text: Ok I have just found a middle-solution. I downloaded a module for Xposed (True silent Mode), after activation you will not able to receive any vibrations or sounds on your phone, but you'll receive a vibration on your watch instead. Hoping Google (or Motorola in our case) fixs it soon...

title: Moto X Play WiFi Calling?

thread.text:
Kind of a black box for me.
Is this a feature that the carrier offers only, or something that needs to be supported by the mobile phone as well?
Does Moto X Play support this?
Thanks
I am not very well versed with the concept of wifi calling(that what it actually mean). But if this something like making a voice call via apps like whatsapp n few others then yes it is supported.

I am not talking about VoIP in the likes of Viber, Whatsapp etc.
I am talking about an option some carriers offer.
When there is no or very bad signal in the area, the phone can call and receive calls normally over a possible WiFi connection instead.
They usually charge the same as the program you have (outgoing calls to the same country or to another country, incoming calls etc.) it is just another way to connect to the phone network

The WiFi calling feature depends on your carrier. Outside the States I've read that EE released it recently in the UK for a limited number of devices and the X Play wasn't included. I'm not sure about other countries. I'll search a bit about this and let you know what I find. Where do you live?

Switzerland. Carrier Salt (ex Orange).
WiFi calling is offered by them for a limited number of devices eg. iphones and Samsungs.
Funnily enough Samsung S5 is included in their list. However my son CAN use this service from his S5, while my wife with another S5 cannot
Not sure then. I think it's related to a software update more than a hardware limitation. Check with them and tell us what they said. I'm quite curious about that

I've just checked with an expert and the short answer for the X Play is no, it can't have WiFi calling for now 
You need some specific firmware in your phone plus the carrier software. For now just a couple of brands and the Nexus line support WiFi calling.

title: Battery and memory difference between X Play and X 2014

thread.text:
Being extremely happy with my X 2014, there was one thing missing
Battery autonomy
Decided to try the X Play, considering its very very big battery capacity
I am now using the X Play with the Sim in, while I have the X 2014 without a Sim card just at my desk.
Both phones have been out of a charger for the last 36 hrs.
The X 2014 has 42% of battery left, with no air time and only 8 minutes of SOT. Its available RAM is at 816 MB.
The X play has 41% of battery left, with 60 mins calls and 2.5 hrs of SOT. Its available RAM is surprisingly enough at 973 MB
The battery difference is very clear between the phones, with the X Play being absolute king here. What I find intruiging is the memory difference, considering both phone have exactly the same apps installed. It seems that again, X Play manages its RAM better than its "father" the X 2014...
Sorry but, What is Xplay? If it is a softwave, pls give me a link
Oh no. I was careless when clik the link through SIMILAR THREADS from battery of S6 Egde, sorry

Which has a better display? Can you tell me the difference in call quality, speakers too... Want to know which one is better..
Posted via moto x play

Display, eh?
OK.
Moto X Play (pluses)
Bigger screen
Brighter, very very brighter screen, easy to see even under direct sunlight
Moto X 2014 (pluses)
Truer color reproduction
AMOLED technology means notifications do not light up the whole screen
Posted via the Android Central App

Can you tell me more comparison between these two phones I.e. performance, battery, OS. Upgradable or not to M etc...
I have the play and my friend is gonna buy the moto x 2014 so would like to know.
Thanks
Posted via moto x play

OK.
Battery. Moto X Play is the ABSOLUTE King. I charge it every second day, while the Moto X 2014, I needed to charge every single day, even midday depending on its use. The Moto X Play is amazing in the battery department, and my best pure or almost pure android phone EVER.
Performance. Moto X 2014 operates very very smoothly. Stutters and lags are a very very rare occurence on this phone. Very happy with it. The Moto X play suffers from stutters and lags. Am I happy with it? No. Is it something that bothers me so much that I cannot stand the phone? Hell no. It is slightly bothersome, but the fact is that all apps operate without a problem, even when multiple apps are open simultaneously. The stuttering occurs, when sliding an app to the side and is immediately visible.
OS. Moto X 2014 runs on 5.1, Moto X Play runs on 5.1.1. Both will receive an upgrade to M. When? Only God and Motorola knows 
All in all, for my usage and needs the Moto X Play wins hands down. Very big, very bright screen, excellent battery autonomy, these are the things I was actually missing from my X 2014. And I have found them at the Moto X Play. It is NOT a flagship phone, it is a very very good middle class phone, and I love it

title: turbo charger

thread.text:
How is the turbo charger? How much time does it take to charge full? 
They haven't launched one in India so I am waiting for it. Is it OK if we play while charging through turbo charger?
Posted via moto x play
You can definitely use it while it is charging

Here in Brazil the phone came with the Turbo charger in the box. The speed of charge depends on how full the battery is and it gets slower the closer it gets to 100%. As an average I would say you can charge 50% in a bit less than an hour (from 30 to 80% for example). 
While turbo charging the phone gets a bit hot. I wouldn't recommend using it a lot while plugged, specially with heavy games, because it can get very hot. Better using a normal charger in those occasions.

Motorola claimed that device will charge 30-40% in the first 15 mins of charging.
Is it true?
Posted via moto x play

Not sure about that. Maybe that rate is for the 20 or 25 Turbo charger models. I'm using the 15 one that came with the phone. As an average I would say you can get 1% of charge, or a bit less, every minute. I'll check next time I use it.

I charged the phone when there was 30% left and checked the level every 15 minutes. It was on WiFi with the usual background processes running. 
30%
46% +16
62% +16
74% +12
86% +12
95% +11
99% +4
It took 8 more minutes to complete the charge.

title: Not able to remove notifications from lock screen sometimes.

thread.text:
Hi,
I purchased new Moto X Play couple of days back and it has been working absolutely fine but now since last 3-4 days, my lock screen gets freezed and i am not able to open it until i press my power button twice, once to turn off the display and again to turn on and then it works fine. The problem doesn't happen all the time but sometimes. I am not sure what's the problem. I am using a glass screen guard purchased locally and i tried to do factory reset and restored my app automatically. Previously sometimes my screen was freezing while on call, e.g. i am on call and i can't disconnect the call without pressing power button twice. After factory reset this problem seems to be gone however i am still getting stuck at lock screen sometimes and touch doesn't work.
Please suggest if there is some hardware issue and i should seek replacement or some app is causing it. I tried searching for answers related to this topic but didn't find any.
Thanks for your response in advance !!

Hi, welcome to the forums! 
Does this happen when a specific notification arrives or is it random? Booting your phone in safe mode will tell if there's a problem with the system or a conflict with an app that you downloaded. 
Just in case, go to settings - security - device administrators and check which apps are included in that list.

Hi Javier,
Thanks for reply! 
It's random and i can define it more likely as 'lock screen gets freezed'. It doesn't happen always but randomly when i leave my phone as idle for sometime and suddenly i find that touch doesn't work at lock screen. If i am actively using phone, there are no issues and no signs of lag or anything. But it happens sometimes on call (touch doesn't work to disconnect the call) and mostly on lock screen. But pressing the power button twice always fixes the issue so it's not a show breaker for me.
I have 'Email' and 'Android device manager' as device administrator and none of the app is having notification access. I didn't try to monitor it in safe mode as issue is random and not always.

Hi, thanks for registering! I'll try to get this thread moved to the X Play forum where you could get more suggestions from other users. 
Which unlock method are you using? Have you enabled any smart lock options? What is it checked in the Moto app, Moto Display, Ambient or none? 
I'm not sure about the email app being checked in the device administrators list, never saw that. Any special reason to be there? You could uncheck it temporarily and see if it makes any difference.

title: Battery life impressions for the Moto X Play

thread.text:
8 hr 15 mins screen on time. Brightness set to adaptive and slider set around 25% on average. GPS location disabled. WiFi and 4G enabled. Usage: heavy web browsing in Chrome via 4G & WiFi with multiple tabs open, YouTube streaming via WiFi, using Tapatalk, Facebook, BBC News app, Android Central app, browsing the Google Play Store, playing Badland etc.
Additionally, this was achieved without the use of the power saving mode built into Lollipop:
Sent from my XT1562 using Tapatalk
That is great but I know I wouldn't get that as I like a nice bright screen

replies.text:
You're probably looking at around 6(ish) hours with higher brightness. Still really impressive. Not many current flagships can boast such endurance.
Sent from my XT1562 using Tapatalk

I agree with my usage at 50% brightness I could reach 6 hours if I used it that much lol. Currently on 65% battery with 2 hours 21 mins screen time and 10 hours 18 mins mobile standby, this phone is a battery beast so far.
I bought it to mess around with, seriously considering selling my LG G4 and using an Honor 7 (have just ordered one) or my Asus Zenfone 2 as a backup: I often use my back up when I am out shooting sports games as a wireless hotspot and so I don't mind if it gets broken!

I personally wouldn't call the X Play a flagship. More like an upper-midranger. The X Style/Pure is the flagship.
That said, that's certainly impressive battery life. Manufacturers need to know that no matter how you can make a phone's hardware much more energy efficient, nothing but a battery that's physically larger in capacity will drastically improve battery life. I'm already tired of the "gimped batteries for a thinner profile" mantra.

I didn't mean to call the Moto X Play a flagship device. I just meant that the battery life is better than pretty much all of the flagships. Obviously less performance, but for some people battery life is top priority.Honestly, I exclusively use mine two handed. I started to gravitate away from one handed use when using the Nexus 5, which for me (I'm short at 5'5" so have tiny hands) was a little too big for comfortable one handed use. Moto X Play certainly is, but this is the smallest 5.5" phone out there because of the small bezels. Other phones with the same screen size, such as the LG G4 and Asus Zenfone 2 are physically bigger than this phone.Amazing! Isn't it just? Battery life and the camera are definitely the greatest aspects of this phone.
Sent from my XT1562 using Tapatalk

Hi guys. I finally decided to get one too, and It's already come. I also ordered a gel case for this model but it hasn't come yet, so today, I left my X Play at home with only 4g on. After idling from 7:30am till 11:00pm, the battery went down ONLY by 5%. 
My Droid RAZR Maxx HD would go down by at least 10% on 3g. That's absolutely brilliant. With my usage and proper settings I think I can do magic with this one.
Oh, and maybe this can be useful for those who suffered too much lags in Chrome. Launch Chrome, go to settings and switch "Merge tabs and apps" option off. After doing that, I went to the 3 sites that people around were mentioning: Android Central, PhoneArena, and The Verge, and I noticed only some minor lags due to pages' loading. However, this will cause your Chrome to appear as a whole app in "recent apps slider", not as separate tabs. Personally, I prefer it this way (got used to it on my Droid).
Cheers guys and have a good night.

title: Moto x play Heating issue

thread.text:
My new phone Moto x play bought on Sept 22, is now facing excessive heat from a week. It was pretty good, now only this heating is bothering me. That too i feel more heat especially while charging(At home). I use the same turbo charger they provided. But while charging with htc charger(at office) doesn’t provide any heat.
My questions:
1. Does charger possess more heat, will changing the charger reduces heat?
2. Will any apps possess heat, uninstalling them reduces heat?
Please reply .. Thanks in advance

Hello, welcome to the forums! 
Turbo charging will generate more heat than using a normal charger. That's normal, but your phone shouldn't get too hot though. Try not to use the phone while plugged in the turbo charger. 
Sometimes the phone will get warmer while on use. Heavy games, long time with screen on, navigation, upload processes running in the background, an app going wild, etc. You could check your battery stats and see if any app shows an unusual high percentage. 
There's a special forum for the Moto X Play. I'll try to get this thread moved over there.
Mod note: Thread moved to proper forum.

title: Looking to buy a Moto X Play.How is the Moto X Play in the gaming department ?

thread.text:
I'm basically looking for some thing which is good for gaming (GTA and such type), camera and a good battery life
Iv'e heard very good things about Moto X play
I don't want an extremely big phone as my hands are a bit small
I don't know how to word it properly but how much does the year of release matter
One of the reasons I'm interested in the moto x play is cause it was released just recently and it's base is the latest android
Ive also read about it being pure android what does that mean
Also since Moto X play has a curved back what difference does it make ?
Also Since I'll be buying a phone during Diwali (indian festival lots of discount) what are the chances of getting a better mobile under 20,000 due to discount and stuff and what are those phone
Right now I only know much about the Moto X Play and not any other phone
Writing it again
I'm basically looking for some thing which is good for gaming (GTA and such type), camera and a good battery life
bump
I was looking into buying the X Play as well, but it seems that it has some performance issues which is disappointing.

My 5 days with the X Play, 32 gb edition Black color. First thing you notice is that it looks stunningly beautiful. The stock android provided is not very good. You cannot totally mute (sound & vibration both) from the dropdown menu bar. You have to go to settings to do it. Screen lock when pattern is opted, you can go on trying. It doesn’t say to send the new pattern to your e mail. Ascending ringtone is not there. Clearing open apps has to be done manually one by one. Data cannot be managed from the dropdown menu. The moment wifi is unavailable; the mobile sim data takes its place. Again to close it you have to go to settings. The audio tunes for ringtone are dumb. But thanks to moto migrate I could get all my data in to the x play. The battery, because of which I bought the phone, is really very very good. After 100% charge I had to start using x play at 4 am. That day I was out till 11:30 pm. I used it properly as I did my redmi 1s, calls, whatsapp, net, games. In the night the battery still had enough juice approx 15%, to last for another 4 hours as the battery indicator said. This thing has won my heart. Now I don’t have to carry power pack everywhere, which was a pain in the back. The camera is too good. The only thing you need to keep in mind is to take pics in normal light. The normal light pics are better than one plus one (which I compared). For gaming I didn't get lots of time to play except 8 ball pool, zombies & some simple games. That was fine. The front facing speaker is what a relief, relief of not setting one of your fingers on the back to direct the sound in the front. The display is very good. Call quality is crisp and clear and loud. As for now I think I made a good decision. But again I must say, this phone in its nude state looks very beautiful.

title: Moto X Play or Moto G 2015 8GB? Fears of stuttering!

thread.text:
I was pretty set on purchasing a Moto X Play... until I started hearing about lag/stuttering issues. I was drawn to the Moto X Play mostly because of stock android in the hope that it would provide a fast and slick interface. I'm not interested in much gaming on my phone, more so just listening to podcasts, browsing the web and social media, checking emails etc. - light stuff. Would a user like me have much issue with the X Play's stuttering?
If so, would I be better off just getting this year's Moto G? I am a poor student so I'm limited to buying a phone on contract and nowhere in the UK seems to offer the 16GB G with the 2GB of RAM, so I am also fearful of seeing stuttering on the 1GB version. It would also be sad to give up the 1080p screen and beast of battery that comes with the Moto X Play.
Any advice?

I think the model with 2gb of RAM is being sold only through Motorola site so it's going to be difficult finding it on a contract. That extra gb will make a big difference with multitasking. 
I've been using the X Play for a few days and didn't notice any lag and just a couple of animation stutters, but barely noticeable. The phone is fast and multitasking is a breeze keeping a long list of apps in the memory. I think some reviews about this phone are a bit unfair. It's a mid-range phone great value for money.

title: Moto X Play: Various Reviews

thread.text:
Found this one so far from android pit https://www.androidpit.com/motorola-moto-x-play-review
Posted via the Android Central App

Thanks for posting!
Key points from review:
- solid build, not flagship premium quality though (plastic)
- great display, little dim in direct sunlight
- fluid software, virtually stock Android
- great general UI performance (no stutters)
- good game performance (Real Racing 3, GTA San Andreas, Sonic Dash etc.)
- no overheating Snapdragon 615
- decent camera for the price, acceptable low light quality, not too much noise, great HDR, overall not as good as top flagship phones of 2015 though (lacks OIS)
- battery that lasts all day (7-8 hours under heavy usage)
Overall sounds like it lives up to the hype in all aspects except for the camera - which is still good but no match for the top Android flagships

I have the Brazil variant XT-1563 and no rattling buttons here. Using this phone heavily for a week, I have no problems with it, but it's not blowing me away either. Big pluses for me are dual sim + SD + FM radio. Camera is **** coming from the Note 4, and so is the stock dialer. (Ok, maybe not ****, but I prefer Sammy's camera and software.) 
Someone asked about headphone audio quality, yes it's perfectly fine. 
Nothing on this phone is really a "wow" except for the battery. I'm getting about a day and a half of heavy usage. Overall this ain't no flagship, just a solid phone for $400. Honestly unless you are dying to have this RIGHT NOW or you need dual sim / fm radio, I would wait for the Moto X Pure Edition that's releasing in the US sometime soon. Too many things missing: gyroscope, stereo speakers, optical image stabilization, no chop twice for flashlight, 4.0 bluetooth instead of 4.1, 32 bit Android instead of 64 (ok the software feels fine but I'm wondering how future proof that will be), no Wifi ac (!!!), screen res at 1080p vs. 1440 on the Pure, 2 gigs ram vs. 3. Also if you jump carriers, the Pure supports way more LTE bands than any variant of the Play. [So far I'm aware of 3, the XT1562 for the UK, XT1563 for Canada and Mexico, and the XT1565 for Verizon with Droid branding. Each variant supports a fairly limited amount of spectrum while the Pure edition seems to have all of em.]
BTW, there's a possibility that my XT-1563 has a few slight differences from ones in Mexico or Canada... mine says Made In Brazil whereas the Mexican XT-1563 says Made In China.

This is the first time I have heard that it's 32bit Android. And you're completely right. I just checked. I don't understand why. It adds no extra cost for the OEM to load 64bit Android onto a phone so this is a really puzzling omission. Is it because 64bit Android takes up more RAM usage?
But honestly cheesiepoof, the FHD screen is one of the best aspects about this device, not sure why you want QHD. The performance would tank and the battery life would suffer greatly.

I guess its all about conprmises. Unfortunately. Droid Life did an article recently saying there is always a BUT with modern smartphone and its certainly true here. 
I prefer the screen of the play, both size and resolution. And i prefer the battery size. It's cheaper too so brilliant, get that! But it has other compromises vs the style so the decision isn't easy.
I've always owned flagships and the play is the first midrange I've considered. Seems a great phone for the money but the reason I'm holding off and waiting for as many reviews and user opinions as possible is that the negatives may not mean its really worth it vs the one m8 I have right now. 
Thanks for all the reviews and opinions from those with the device. Really helpful
Posted via the Android Central App

I think the best way to sum it up is that it feels more like a souped-up Moto G on steroids rather than a scaled back Moto X Style. It offers a lot more than the Moto G can; much better display, better GPU performance, better camera, smaller bezels, more refined design etc. but there is a larger gulf between the Moto X Style and the Moto X Play than the Moto G and the Moto X Play. 
I am certainly not regretting my decision but I am not being blown away by this phone as I was hoping I would be. I wanted a phone that would completely replace my Nexus 5, but this phone acts as more of a sidegrade - noticeably better in some areas (battery, camera, speaker quality, display, SD card support, haptic feedback) and worse in others (lack of gyroscope & other sensors, not quite as smooth in the Android UI, rattly buttons).

What areas is it worse than the nexus 5? I don't use mine any more but have played around with it on 5.1.1 and it feels really fluid and snappy. I'd be back using it if the battery wasn't so terrible! Is it performance of the play vs the nexus or down to build quality or...? I guess the camera must be better and the battery at least
Posted via the Android Central App

replies.text:
Yes, performance isn't quite as slick in general use i.e. the Material UI animations, time it takes to install apps, 3D performance. Not a huge difference but noticeable for someone who has used Nexus 5 since it launched (though I would say that Moto X Play offers a better experience than the Nexus 5 did with Android 5.0-5.1 with that awful memory leak/borked background app management).
Other notable areas of downgrade are the lack of gyroscope and other sensors. I have looked at several hardware info apps and the gulf between the number of sensors installed on these phones is quite big - granted, the majority of the ones on the Nexus 5 are going to be used rarely in everyday usage scenarios (e.g. barometer, gravity sensor etc.). The gyroscope is the biggest omission here but also notable is the lack of a dedicated step counter, though whether that impacts apps like Google Fit I am yet to find out - will report back later today on that.
The build quality is about the same. Moto X Play has rattly (i.e. loose fitting) buttons and yet the Nexus 5 has a much inferior haptic feedback (the vibration engine is noisier and doesn't generate as pleasing vibrations - hey, stop it with your dirty mind!).
The battery and camera are miles better than the Nexus 5, I can already tell. Low-light camera performance is much closer between them but the Moto X Play still wins out slightly, which is impressive as it manages this without OIS.

What I mean is: a regular user would not care about 64 bit Android, or more ram... I was a Nexus fan, had many of them even when they were not sold in my country. I don't see how this is great for the price if the Pure edition is expected to sold at the same price point, roughly $400 USD? Even if you get this for $350 or even $300, I think this is too much money for a “just ok” phone.
Here's my final summary after 10 days of heavy use. Keep in mind that I'm using the XT-1563 variant made in Brazil (Build number: LPD23.118-6.1, system version: 23.41.1.lux_relta_ds.retla.en.01 retbr) so if you have the XT-1562 or the upcoming XT-1565 you'll have some minor software differences not to mention single sim not dual.
Things I like:
- battery charges quickly - not blazing and not as fast as an iOS device - but fast enough
- battery lasts all day on heavy use
- plenty of storage
- dual sim + FM radio
Don't like:
- micro lag, unacceptable on a new phone with 8 cores
- screen responsiveness: occasionally need to swipe something 2 or 3 times - lock screen in particular
- 4.0 bluetooth interferes with LTE - where's 4.1? 
- slow to switch from wifi to cellular data - totally unacceptable
- dull FHD screen, and dim in sunlight
- camera is below average
- where's my chop chop to flashlight? oh, they didn't include a gyroscope, great.
Camera: Most online reviews are not raving about it, and I think they're actually being too kind. It's ACCEPTABLE, but nowhere near even a 2 year old Apple or Samsung device in picture quality or software, I'm sorry. 
Screen: it's possible I just got a dud. It's not terrible, I'm just not impressed. Perhaps my "Made in Brazil" XT-1563 is not up the standard of the other ones reviewed here. Different materials?
Other things that don't affect my user experience yet, but leave me scratching my head:
- no wifi ac
- 32 bit android
This phone is just ok. Literally NOTHING on this phone impresses me, everything is just good enough or occasionally, not up to snuff, like a switch from wifi to cellular data taking 30 seconds.
My recommendation: No!! Get the Style / Pure.
Hopefully that helps someone.

In WiFi settings you can allow WiFi scanning always available. The location services then uses this to help with location even if u have WiFi switched off. It think this constant looking at the location is a big drain which of course Google now needs to do often to give u the relevant information. 
I believe dose in android 6 uses the accelerometers to sense the fact that the phone isn't moving and then it won't look for your location which will make a big difference. When you are moving around it will always be working out your location though if you use Google now.

I really like the feel of it. I had a one m8 but to be honest it put me off metal phones. If u used it naked it was hard to hold and it scratched and denred easily. If you out a case on it then what was the point of paying for the premium design!

I was able to get 35,693 in the Antutu benchmark with this phone. My Nexus 5 got 39,526. This device isn't that bad, it's the Android OS itself that needs optimising. Specifically for multi-threaded workloads which is the Snapdragon 615's strength rather than single-core performance, which is its weakness.

thread.text:
My uncle going to the trip to London next Tuesday and I want him to buy me Moto X play but I have some questions
1. How is the build quality? Is the phone feel cheap? 
2. How the screen quality?
3.How is the phone run on 615 processor?
4 Is the body very thick because the battery size?
I don't mind for LTE in my area H+ is still very fast..
Thanks.

replies.text:
1) Yes. It feels robust and solid. Only aspect that feels cheap are the power and volume buttons. They are slightly loose fitting and while this doesn't affect actually using them at all, it does occasionally mean that they produce a slight audible rattle depending on how you are holding the phone. That is literally my only complaint about the build quality.
2) It's great. Nice and bright. Colours look nice and saturated. Contrast is high. It's nice and sharp too. Compared to the Nexus 5 display, it's definitely a slight improvement. It's not an AMOLED, but it's one of the best FHD IPS LCDs out there.
3) Not as fast as the Nexus 5 and the Snapdragon 800, but it's not horrible experience either. Animations are a bit choppier than you would expect from a modern flagship. The majority of 3D games run fine, just again, not quite as well as the Nexus 5. In terms of multitasking, it's a champ and can handle plenty of apps running at once (including Chrome) without purging background apps from memory. 
4) It's 10.9mm thick at its thickest point, but doesn't feel it because it's curved. It feels very ergonomic and comfortable to hold in the hand.

thread.text:
Same software version here. By the way I had some Motorola app updates (including Moto app, Gallery app, Camera app and more) that I could install but Google Play Store didn't automatically install these updates for me. I came across them accidentally when searching for Motorola apps in the Play Store. Updated them all. Gallery and Camera apps get some new features and the rest offer bug fixes, so worth installing.
More performance tips for ya guys/gals:
1) If you're using Adguard and want the permanent notification gone, there's a way to do that. First, go the settings menu in the app, navigate to general and find the notification setting in the list. Simple as that!
2) If you want to improve the experience even further using Adguard you can go to settings, navigate to advanced and tick the box that says 'Filter DNS requests'. This has improved performance further and has seemingly decreased the battery impact of Adguard slightly.
3) If you want to use an alternative to Adguard you can download Firefox and use any one of the adblocking add ons. Probably Adblock is the best bet as that has been specifically optimised for Android. This has the benefit of not requiring the permanent VPN icon.
4) Another alternative is Adblock Browser, currently in beta. A simple Google search will lead you to the download link. This is based upon the Firefox browser so the experience is largely the same as going the Firefox + add on route.
5) To improve launcher animations (notably the app drawer expand/contract animation) you can install Nova Launcher from the Play Store. This seems to be better optimised than the Google Now launcher. Animations in the launcher become noticeably smoother. I think this last point is really important as it shows that software optimisation can really help improve performance on this device, so there is hope that future updates to various apps will boost animation smoothness and general responsiveness.
Sent from my XT1562 using Tapatalk

thread.text:
Hi,
Can folks who are suffering lag try a couple of little experiments for me? I'm wondering if the lag is related to a bug in the CPU Governor that is present is at least one other Moto phone. The symptoms sounds similar.
First off download CPU Spy Reloaded or a similar CPU monitoring app - https://play.google.com/store/apps/d...nna.cpuspyfree
Then reboot the phone - use as normal for 15 mins to 30 mins except do not touch the camera! Get a screenshot of the bar chart output of CPU Spy.
Reboot again - take a ccouple of photos with the main camera and then use as normal for 15mins to 30 mins. Get a screenshot of the bar chart output of CPU Spy.
You are looking for a clearly different pattern of Clock Speeds after camera use along with more lagginess after camera use.
Also if anyone can post screenshots from Settings/Developer Options/Process Stats they would be interesting to see.
Finally are folks seeing Music Players in the background being chucked out of memory and under what circumstances? Can you reliably use for example Play Music and Maps to navigate at the same time (this latter is my biggest bugbear with my current original Moto G)..

Also, I tested playing music via Poweramp and started loading more apps including navigation via Google Maps. Music kept on playing throughout, no issues whatsoever.

thread.text:
A couple of reviews along with numerous posters have remarked that this phone just isn't performing that well during regular use. AC's own review summed it up nicely:
"Given the decidedly wonky performance we've seen from the Play, it's interesting to go back to Motorola's budget champion, the*Moto G. Sure, the G is pushing far fewer pixels, but it's also packing a much less powerful CPU and the same amount of RAM, and yet every time the G feels like the faster phone. That's a shame, because in most other areas the Play is a joy to use. When you consider all the engineering effort made by Google in recent years to eliminate lag in Android, it's slightly surreal to be going back to 2012-13 levels of stutteriness in a current handset."
That is indeed a damn shame. The build quality issues I've been reading about coupled with the above has unfortunately placed this firmly on my don't buy list. The camera, battery, nice looks, and moto software features had me all set to buy this phone thinking I'd be getting a good deal for $400. But even at that price I don't think expecting less stutter, no iffy buttons, no gaps collecting dust is truly too much to ask for. Combine all this with lenovo totally replacing the original software team bringing all future software updates into uncertain territory, and there's no way I can possibly feel like this phone is a confident purchase.
I don't know what's going on in Android OEM land these days, they all seem to be dedicated to shooting themselves in the foot in some significant way or another and not a single one this year to date has had the wherewithal to just sit down and say "hey we just made an awesome phone, so let's not ruin all the positives by putting [insert big mistake here] in it" 
Is that one simple bit of common sense seriously too much to ask for?

@Cakefish - Thanks for checking it out - nothing untoward in your results that I can see. Process stats looks very healthy, and the CPU speed governor bug I suspected doesn't seem to be there (reverting to the minimum clock speed as a base after camera use). Looks like Moto have set a pretty high base clock speed (if it's on it's running at 960Mhz) - really surprising that it lags in those circumstances.

For me I think it depends if things can be fixed in software and if they can whether Motorola support the device properly with timely and regular updates. If they do then I'm happy. Buying a phone as soon as it comes out is always a risk and they all require a few sotware updates before they reach their potential. Who knows, maybe Motorola hadn't quite polished the final software but decided to still release it on schedule with an older build and the plan to update soon after launch. After all articles I have read suggested chop chop for flashlight was removed at the last minute so it may make an appearance in an update soon.
As for build quality issues. Obviously that can't be addressed with an updates but what are they? The buttons are poor no doubt and I mark it down for that but otherwise its excellent with great form factor and in hand feel. If it had better buttons it would be bang on ideal but even without its still up there as one of the best I've owned

Mine arrived yesterday. The phone feels great in the hand and seems much lighter than I thought, easy to use one handed. I haven't noticed any lag so far even while downloading and installing all my apps. Multitasking is great and even "weak" apps that use to be killed soon stay open a long way back in the recent apps list. 
Setting a new phone up was good to confirm that I really like Nova  Restored my whole setup, including Zooper, and animations are very smooth. With this big screen Nova gestures and Zooper "on tap actions" are more useful than ever. 
Here in Brazil they included the Turbo charger in the box, and it's fast  Very happy so far.

Awww you get the Turbo Charger included? We Brits are being screwed over. As always with technology and electronics *sigh*
Glad you like it! Welcome to the club 
@neu smurph - I think it's the GPU that's not quite powerful enough to display the animations at FHD entirely smoothly. I don't think it's an issue with the CPU.
Sent from my XT1562 using Tapatalk

The only build quality issue I have are those slightly loose buttons. Yes, they are a minor annoyance, but I'm quickly becoming accustomed to them. They feel comfortable to use, it's just the noise they occasionally make in quiet environments that can mildly irritate. The rest of the phone feels very solid and robust though.
Yeah, chop chop needs to come back to make this phone feel complete. Why? Only because the cheaper Moto G has the feature. Motorola really needs to add it in an update ASAP! We should pester them about this, not let them forget!
And yes, animation smoothness isn't as slick as I originally had hoped but it could potentially be improved with future updates. Gotta have hope!

Yeah, the physical buttons are a bit loose and look a bit cheap. I like the size and position though. With the Active display and my lock screen app I won't be using those buttons much so it doesn't bother me.

I haven't tried any games on my play but I've heard most run pretty well which makes it seem strange that the GPU can handle games but not simple animations in the UI. 
I'm still hopeful Motorola can fix it through software updates. It won't let me check for updates now saying check later whereas before it said I was up to date so maybe something is being prepared....??! Of course probably not!

thread.text:
My decision on buying the Play was based on 2 wants:
- a decent camera
- a battery that, regardless of use during the day, only requires charging once each day - i.e. overnight (I work in an office with every poor reception and find that my current Moto X needs charging every afternoon and overnight)
I also felt that the Pure/Style was too big, the Play being not much bigger than my current Moto X. In the end I want a phone that works for me - I don't feel the need for it to have the best camera, the highest resolution screen, be the thinnest, be the fastest. On the last point I just hope the 615 CPU doesn't cause me too many problems, although thanks to these forums there are solutions.
As far as prices go, simply comparing UK/US and adding 20% isn't correct. What about US state tax and UK duty?
I haven't received my Play yet (9th Sept!), but so far I don't regret it

Looking at the clove price in the UK for the style, its £100 more than my play from CPW. That is for double the storage and if the style includes the turbo charger in the box as well then the difference isn't maybe so great. But its still £100 at the end of the day and I'm supposed to be saving up for a wedding next year!
I just hope Motorola sort the lag issues out that I'm seeing sooner rather than later. I don't need the fastest phone in the world but jerky scrolling rally shouldn't happen when the moto g doesn't. Then it'll be just about perfect for me. 
I too work in an office with poor signal and my one m8 would be down to 15% by the end of the day. The play sadly doesn't do low signal that well either but it still trumps the one m8 giving me enough left to get through the evening too without charging
Posted via the Android Central App

thread.text:
I just got mine today, to me it feels like a really solid well built phone. Obviously it's not glass or metal all over, but theres no creeks, the plastic doesn't push in like old samsung phones, the plastic back feels really nice to hold, and grippy (not slippery like some metal/glass phones) and the edges don't feel plasticky to me, even if they are. I'm also quite fond of the way it looks. Yes the buttons move, but it doesn't bother me, I've had a lot of phones that have slightly loose buttons. They feel fine and are nice and clicky. 
Also on the build, i'm really impressed how small this phone is for a 5.5 inch screen phone. It is pretty much the same size as my oppo r7 (5 inch screen), it's BARELY wider and taller. Obviously the oppo is a lot thinner, but because the sides of the moto x play are slimmer, it doesn't feel thick holding on to it

thread.text:
I solved both the slipperiness (although I didn't find the phone that slippery, I was just worried about dropping it) and the rattling buttons with a cheap, simple case the covers the back of the phone. 
Regarding the lag/stutter I haven't found it that noticeable or annoying, but I guess everyone's perception is different - and what phone you came from might be a factor. Today I did notice the animations slow in Todoist. So I tried a trick I remember seeing on an MKBHD video. Enable developer options and then change each of the following options to 0.5 (from 1.0):
- window animation scale
- transition animation scale 
- animator duration scale
Early days but it solved the slow animations in Todoist.

thread.text:
First impression - beautiful phone. Love the red accent I picked in Moto Maker. Loving the big screen. Very nice to have!
Really not liking the fact that Motorola didn't include Turbo charger. Hoping I can track one down in town today. The charger they do provide is awfully, painfully slow.
Power and volume buttons are rattly and a bit loose. Nothing major, but a minor issue seeing as my Nexus 5 doesn't have this problem.
Screen is better quality than Nexus 5. More saturated colours, more accurate whites and deeper blacks. Not a colossal difference, but definitely noticeable when viewed side-by-side. Much nicer haptic feedback too; doesn't make as much noise.
Speaker is definitely better on the Moto X. More punchy, louder and more bass.

title: How long does Moto Display appear (LCD) on the Moto X Play?

thread.text:
I've got one of the new 2015 Moto X's. I have noticed that this feature is not as convenient for me as everyone says it is, as it has a very aggressive timeout before the display switches off again. This means that I rarely have time to react to the notification before it's gone. So I'm wondering whether Motorola has cut down this timeout period relative to the Moto X 2014 due to the LCD displays on the new Moto X phones and not the AMOLED of years past.
Sent from my XT1562 using Tapatalk

The initial notification seems to be approx 2 seconds, while breathing notifications seem to start fading at 4 seconds and disappear at 5 seconds. Note, waving your hand over the device (IR sensors on the bottom) or picking it up will typically cause breathing notifications to occur prior to the normal cycle.

I think the second gen Moto E and third gen Moto G have the same behavior because they use LCDs too.
Posted via Android Central App (Moto X)
Just wave at the phone and the notification comes back.

replies.text:
Not on Moto X Play. It lacks the IR sensors needed for that.
I wish Moto would allow some customisation of the length until screen timeout. It's currently too short.
Sent from my XT1562 using Tapatalk
Oh, wrong forum, then.
Moved to Moto X Play forum.

thread.text: So does the blinking display timeout sooner than it did on the x2 with a amoled display?

title: Video recording issues?

thread.text:
Hi, I recieved my Moto X Play today and have really enjoyed using it until this evening. 
However, whenever iI try and record video (1080p), there seem to be 2 problems:
1) It zooms in a bit when the record button is pressed (not sure if this is normal (i.e changing aspect ratio), can somebody test it for me please?)
2) This is far worse - there is significant lag on the screen, as in it if i move the phone it take a short while to show any movement on the screen :/
I've tried resetting the Moto camera app, and not saving things onto an SD card (my SD card should be fast enough for there to be no issues anyway).
Because it's the evening, I'm wondering if this has something to do with the low light conditions? Could somebody please experiment for me and see if the same happens to them in low light? Obviously I'll test again in the morning, but this is on my mind rn >_<.
EDIT: Downloaded Google Camera and there's no issue whatsoever.. therefore this is an issue with the Motorola Camera App, which is ridiculous - I don't think this is a common issue, anyone got any ideas for a fix?

Update: The Lag is less obvious in better light. I've concluded that it's caused by a video stabilisation system. I think there should be an option to disable it tbh. As for it zooming in, that's simply annoying (as the Google Camera maintains the same fov when recording).

I just checked mine and no lag at all on decent light. Not got the opportunity to try low light at the mo. 
Have you taken any photos with the Google camera app? How does it compare to the moto app?
Posted via the Android Central App

replies.text:
Mine's not really lagging at the moment, but the stabilisation system feels strange. Does yours zoom in a little when you press the record button?
I prefer the Moto Camera over the Google Camera because the Moto one has the exposure control. There's plenty of camera apps on the Playstore so I'm testing out a few.

thread.text:
Yes it does zoom in. Didn't notice it the first time. Must be something to do with the way it uses the sensor I guess
Posted via the Android Central App
Oh Ok, that's reassuring . If you want video with a greater fov (albeit no stabilisation) then the Google Camera works for that.

Perhaps the stabilisation works by using less if the sensor as the actual image and using the outlying pixels to adjust for camera shake. Hence the zoomed in view
Posted via the Android Central App

title: Will a 200GB micro SD card work in the Moto X Play?

thread.text:
Hi,
I currently use the LG G4, and have one of San Disk's new 200gb Micro SD's in it.
I know, like other manufacturers, Motorola state the max MSD capacity is 128gb, but I'm hoping that the XPlay may be OK with 200gb (as is the Sony Z3 which also states 128gb max, for example).
I think the rule of thumb is that manufacturers who currently state a 128gb max likely do more-so because, at time of 'speccing', 128gb was the most common maximum, rather than not being able to accept the larger variant.
I'd be interested if anyone has tried this (unlikely), or has any other opinions. I'm toying with getting the Xplay as a 2nd device, but if I can't just pop the my SD card in/out of that and the G4, it renders it a little pointless.
Cheers.
NB: I did have an on-line chat with Motorola UK, but I just got the standard 'We cannot guarantee it will work as it states...'.

replies.text:
I have 16gb with a 64gb SD card.
Posted via the Android Central App

Depends on how many apps and games you want to install. Keep in mind that the internal memory will always be slightly faster than even a fast UHS micro SD card. Also, the more empty space there is on a eMMC SSD, the better the performance. Obviously that doesn't necessarily mean that 32GB is bound to be faster - there are other potential bottlenecks (e.g. CPU).
That said, if I had the choice today to go for 16GB at £250 or 32GB at £319 I'd go for the former, without doubt. It's borderline having to pay £40 extra for double the storage but £70? I don't think it's worth it. If you intend on buying the 16GB version from Moto Maker anyway then the decision becomes harder as it can be handy to have a larger internal memory and £40 difference is a lot less than a £70 difference.

Typically it's the width, not the height that bothers people. And you can have a phone with a 5.5" display, that's much more difficult to hold than a 5.7" one.
Hopefully you'll enjoy the smaller Nexus this year. And I'm more of a fan of the larger phones, but I do feel sorry for the people that prefer more compact devices. Obviously, you don't need the same specs (resolution, processor, battery, etc) in a smaller device that you'll find on a larger one in order to achieve the same performance, but it's too bad that space isn't filled with more choice. I don't think it's a case of a vocal minority. I mean yeah they might be vocal (OK, they are!) and yeah they're the minority, but I do believe there's a market.

title: Motorola Promises Next Gen Moto X Will have Kickin' Camera

thread.text:
Perhaps the next gen Turbo will have the improved camera as well. Maybe they read JamieLov's posts here.
-----------------
With zero offense meant to Motorola, given that the company is known for making fantastic hardware as a whole, the cameras found in its flagship devices, notably the Moto X (1st Gen and 2nd Gen), have been rather unpleasant to use during most shooting circumstances. Even though Motorola has worked hard to update its camera software via firmware updates and camera app updates, the shooters just aren’t all that good when compared to other offerings on the market. 
On Twitter yesterday, Motorola’s CMO Adrienne Hayes, says the company is working hard to change that this year, stating, “We know we need to improve here and are definitely going to ‘bring it.'”
When asked if Motorola would work to bring an advanced manual camera mode to the next flagship, plus improve on imaging as a whole, Hayes replied with, “We absolutely can and we absolutely will this year.”http://www.droid-life.com/2015/06/09...rd-gen-camera/
I really hope they plan on using the S6 and G4 as the comparison shots when they're testing that.

Like I said, I predict a better camera Droid this year perhaps called something like the "Droid Capture". 
If there is one thing that moto got wrong the last couple of years, it's photography. It's good to see them acknowledge it. 
I still probably won't buy it, though. (I have an upgrade coming this August.)

The issue isn't at the app level, or even the kernel. LG and Samsung didn't build better cameras - everyone had basically the same sensors and lenses - they paid tens if not hundreds of millions of dollars to license the image processing technology from real camera companies who've been doing digital photography for decades.
Nexus/aosp will NEVER get that level of image processing, because the people who own the technology will never let it go open source.

title: My Hands-On with the Moto X Play in Brazil

thread.text:
I just came back from a Motorola kiosk in Sao Paulo.
They just released the Moto X Play here in brazil.
I went there to check in hands the quality, size, screen and camera.
I wasn't considering buying it anyways, but I just wanted to check how some of the components would hold, specially because I'm waiting for the Style/Pure.
The screen seems good. Comparing to my LG G4, it seems as bright, and has good viewing angles. Nothing wrong I could spot on my 5 minutes with the phone in hand. The resolution is 1080p that I think is the sweet spot for phones. I think the QHQ on my G4 is overkill.
The phone seems very well build and fits pretty well in the hand. It's almost the same size as G4, a few mm smaller on the sides, but the rounded edges and beziers help the ergonomics a lot.
The camera is supposedly the same from X Style, so I tried to compare it to my LG G4 camera (the best mobile camera I've ever seen in my life. I'm a professional advertisement photographer.)
The camera seems good, but it's no comparison to LG G4, and I imagine neither to S6.
The lack of OIS I think it's bad for a heavy and big phone, because unless you shoot using both hands, it tends to be unbalanced.
And with a BIG resolution, those small vibrations will transform into blurred pictures.
And the software is the same from last year, so I think it's a little to simple for my taste. I would love an advanced mode, like samsung and LG does.
It's a step forward to 2014 one, but still no comparison to LG and Samsung top cameras.

replies.text: and what about comparison btw xperia phones?

thread.text:
I don't have many experience with xperia phones to compare.
I mostly used nexus and motorola devices in my life. And now I have the G4.
The screen seems at first glance comparable, although with less resolution, to the incredible screen of the G4.
The camera seems OKAY. A little better than Moto Maxx (Droid Turbo).
After the G4, my expectation of camera quality has raised a lot.

The X Play battery will probably hold longer thant the Droid Turbo/Moto Maxx.
The screen has less resolution, the processor is more energy efficient and slower, and some people argue about AMOLED with QHD (droid turbo/moto maxx) been more power hungry than a bigger TFT panel with 1080p.
So I really expect X Play to hold for two whole days.

title: Predictions: Moto X Play potential battery life?

thread.text:
First a quick rant; There's been so many hands-on preview articles/videos made about the Moto X Style and Moto G but all the tech media seen to have almost completely overlooked the Moto X Play. I can only assume this is because most are American. I want this phone desperately but trying to find hands-on articles/videos is like trying to find gold dust in a sea of Moto X Style and G previews. End rant.
Anyway, seeing as there's a similar thread for the Style, I thought I'd do the same for the Play. 
Here's what we've got: 
- efficient lower-powered SOC
- 'only' a FHD display
- that 3630mAh battery!
- no bloatware installed
I wonder what the screen-on time will be like? Obviously better than the Style, last year's Moto X and the Droid Turbo. Better than all the flagships from LG, Sony etc too. I've been looking at all the phones with the largest battery capacities and they all use higher-powered SOCs and/or have QHD displays. So this phone is really exciting as we haven't seen the low-powered Snapdragon 615 paired with a battery of this size yet. It'll be one hell of an upgrade over my current Nexus 5, which struggles to handle more than two hours of screen-on time with my usage patterns (heavy web browsing)!

replies.text: Apparently the 615 isn't great on battery usage, and is more of a battery hog than the 8xx series chips (minus the 810) at least that is what David on AndroidPolice was saying, hence why they went so large battery on the play and "only" 3000mah on the style.

Hmmm. That's disappointing to hear.
Sony has just announced a direct competitor to this phone - the Xperia M5. It's got a 2600mAh battery and a Helio X10. Will it have longer battery life despite the much smaller battery?
Sent from my Nexus 5 using Tapatalk
That's one point of view. Although, I've seen a lot of reviews with other phones that use the same 615 chipset and that don't have battery issues.

His opinion here: https://plus.google.com/113781386215...ts/ai1NGyKnKLS
And if you look approximately half way down his editorial on Snapdragon In general where he brings up the 615: http://www.androidpolice.com/2015/08...-from-the-top/ its not terribly reassuring.
I was initially very excited about this phone - not least because of the battery size - but now I'm not so sure so definitely hanging fire on this one.

Holy ****. Here's positively spitting venom at the 615. Really souring my enthusiasm for this phone 
But what other options are there in this price bracket that will be available by the end of this month? I can only think of the Xperia M5 with the Helio X10 SOC - but it has a mere 2600mAh battery.
Sent from my Nexus 5 using Tapatalk

I want to see other points of views. This is only one guy. I've made a research about other phones that uses the same 615 (HTC desire 820, Alcatel...) and the reviewers indeed say that the battery have issues, but the bigger battery (HTC desire) only has 2600 mah
Now the question is, even with this bad SD 615, it's gonna be equal or worse than other phones?

X Play Battery pontential vs Xperia M5 vs MX4 Pro vs Moto Maxx

title: Motorola - Missed opportunity

thread.text:
I love what Moto has done the last couple years and I really had high expectations for the 2015 but I really fell they missed an opportunity to release 1 amazing phone rather than 2 good phones. I know they are intended for different markets but here's how I would have updated the Moto X 2014
- Keep 5.2" 1080p screen from LY (If they had to go 5.5 based on cost, i'm ok with that if they use smaller bezels). I dont mind Qhd screen but not necessary due to cost and battery life impact
- 3600mAh batter from Moto X play
- Snapdragon 808 processor
- Starting at $349/399 for $16gb w/SD card
Why the large phablet? The appeal of the Moto X 2013 was mainly its size and the option in the market to have a phone easier to use in one hand when everyone is releasing large phones. I think it was a miss in the nexus 6 and now the Moto X. I know there's a significant market for Phablets but no one seems to be catering to the 5" phone with high end specs (except maybe GS6 but even that feels a tad too tall due to the home button)
I too was hoping for a hybrid device and a phone device, so say a 5.7" and a 5.0-5.2" To be honest, I am kind of looking at the Moto G.

I agree about the size. I was also hoping for a 5.2" device, but I understand the commercial reasons after this Motorola move. The new X Play is about the same size than a LG G4 (top shelf) and a Zenfone 5 (bottom one) and with specs and price right in the middle. I think the 5" size will be back with the new Turbo/Maxx generation to be presented in September. And as Golfdriver said we always have the Moto G with 2gb

Motorola wanted to fill three price points (globally). 
$200, $300, $400 = Moto G, Moto X Play, Moto X Style. 
I would rather they have called the Moto X Play a "Moto <insert letter between G and X here>" (like a Moto M?) to help avoid confusion in markets where all three phones are available.
Posted via Android Central App (Moto X)

I also don't understand why the flagship device wouldn't have the best of all specs....Why didn't the Style also get the big battery? Its not competing with the Play anyway. I will have to assume they are reserving that battery for the Droid line which sucks

replies.text:
I actually like the droid line, but thats my opinion. It still surprises me that motorola doesnt put a bigger in their flagships. The droid turbo has a 3900mah battery and the phone is a good size. Its not part of the "slim is in" like apple or samsung, but its not too thickeither.
I wonder why, esp since the x play isnt avalible in the US the new style doesnt have a little bit bigger battery. I cant see they only save the big batteries for the droid line. 3000mah is still on the small side when you consider a 5.2 or larger screen.
Posted via the Android Central App

thread.text:
The Style is slimmer than the Play. That's why it has a smaller battery.
Play; 8.9 - 10.9mm
Style; 6.1 - 11.06mm
Its back is a lot more curved so unless they added the fancy new stacked battery tech from Apple's new Macbook they were limited by physical space.
The Style was designed to be attractive, fashionable and sleek (it's in the name). The Play was designed to be robust, long-lasting and dependable.
Sent from my Nexus 5 using Tapatalk

replies.text:
The Style is actually thicker than the Play with a smaller battery and bigger display. Pretty odd if you ask me.
Posted via the Android Central App

Thicker at its thickest point. Thinner at its thinnest point. A lot more curved. Maybe they just couldn't physically fit a larger battery inside without making the phone thicker.
Or perhaps they left it out for cost reasons to get to the $399 US price point. As the Play already makes substantial cuts to the SOC and display they might have had more wiggle room to add a larger battery and stay at the targeted price point.
Or another option is that they deliberately wanted the Play to have a bigger battery to give it a compelling unique feature that sets it apart from the rest of their lineup. So maybe they deliberately made sure the battery was larger than the Style's to better differentiate the two models.
