title: Is the Moto X Play a worthy upgrade over the Nexus 5 (2013)?

thread.text:
I currently have the Nexus 5. I love it, for the most part. It fits my needs fine in most aspects. I have just two issues with the phone and unfortunately they're pretty major; camera quality and battery life. Low light camera performance is abysmal even with OIS and the battery life is extremely short with my usage patterns (mostly YouTube and tons of web browsing).
So I'm questioning whether this phone is suitable for me. I understand that the Snapdragon 615 is a downgrade over the Snapdragon 800 but I'm wondering whether the huge boost in battery and the better camera are worthy trade-offs. Plus, this phone has SD card support which is a huge bonus as well as front-firing speakers, which is an improvement over the Nexus 5.
The other option I have is, of course, the Moto X Style - still torn between waiting for that or getting the Play. I'm wondering how much faster it really is at playing Android games - the Adreno 418 had to power that QHD display while the Adreno 405 only had to power a FHD display with the Play. Will the difference actually balance out when taking display resolution into account?
As for alternatives, unfortunately, the Nexus 5 2015 is releasing too late in the year for my liking - I don't think I can wait until November(ish) to solve my battery life and camera woes. The rumoured Sony Xperia Z5 Compact, while sounding very exciting, will likely be a bit out of my price range for this year - with the Z3 Compact retailing at £429 at launch.

Im wondering the same thing. I actually gave up on my nexus 5 for the one m8 as the battery life was so poor but the one m8 on lollipop is nowhere near as good as it was in its KitKat days. I feel I need a new phone and the play is appealing. 
Personally I hate lag and jerkiness in software so the lower end processor is a concern but will it really matter in real world usage? The battery looks awesome and is exactly what I need. The screen is a good size and a sensible resolution. 
I do wonder what the nexus 5 2015 will be and it all comes down to how they price it. The biggest missing feature on the play is the fingerprint sensor which the next nexus will have and is supported in M so its a shame they left it off the Play. How much that matters I don't know but I am a big fan of touch id on the iPhone
Posted via the Android Central App
It's a difficult decision - get the play asap or wait for the style. I would like to see a side by side video comparison of both devices.

title: What market is the Moto X Play intended for?

thread.text: basically it looks like a budget android phone with a giant battery. But they already have a new budget phone (Moto G). I'm guessing the G is supposed to fill the low end segment and the Play is midrage? Ok, but if that's the case their flagship specced phone is only $400 but cut a couple of corners which also qualifies IMO as mid-range. There's also only a 0.2' difference in screen size. Not sure why Moto even bothered with the Play version, it seems kind of redundant.

I think they missed the mark with the two X's being so close in size. They should have gone with one 5.2 inches and the other 5.7. I agree they made some interesting, if not strange spec decisions. I think they were strongly motivated to hit particular price points. I think the Verizon Droid variant will have most of the goodies spec wise, but with of course a higher price or going on contract/Edge agreement.

Nice size. A small step up from my Turbo (about 4mm taller) / same width, without going too large - the Style is 10mm taller and 3 mm wider. Just need to know how this processor compares to the Snapdragon 805 in the turbo

thread.text:
A 3,280 mAh battery and 4 GB of RAM? I'm certainly intrigued with a 64 GB option. Although can someone explain the difference between the Snapdragon 808 and 810, and what would be lost/gained aside from the overheating issue?
Posted via the Android Central App

replies.text: 808 is a 6 core chip while the 810 is an 8 core. There is no real difference in day-to-day tasks between the two chips. However, there is a slight difference in heavy intensive graphics. The 808 uses Adreno 418 vs the Adreno 430 in the 810. You would only notice this in playing graphic intense games.

I've read conflicting statements, more more that have said the 810 when throttled is equal to the 801 sometimes. Where there's smoke there's fire, I wouldn't get a device with the 810 ... Anxious to see the 820.
Posted via the Android Central App

1. QI WIRELESS FREAKING CHARGING FOR GOD'S FREAKING SAKE, MOTOROLA! 
Coming from several phones with Qi Charging, I feel like I've stepped back into The Charging Stone Ages when I use my Moto X 2013 & 2014. Ugh!
If Motorola managed to put Qi charging into the Nexus 6 then they can do it with the next Moto X. It's getting to a point were I'm thinking of not buying Moto again because they keep leaving it out for no good reason!
2. Better/Bigger Battery: I took a downgrade in battery life when I "upgraded" from a Moto X 2013 to the 2014. Please either a bigger battery or better battery optimization.
3. BETTER CAMERA WITH OPTICAL IMAGE STABILIZATION! Tired. Of. Garbage. Camera!! There's no excuse for a [language] camera like this on a flagship device nowadays. Fix the garbage camera sensors and half-baked camera app!
4. Fingerprint Scanner: That huge dimple is clearly the resulting (large) crater of a Fingerprint Scanner hastily abandoned at the last minute. 
Please add a Fingerprint scanner to use for unlocking the phone and other things like paying with PayPal or, one day, Google Wallet/NFC payments like Apple Pay... 
(And one day using it to log you into website and apps without having to enter PINs and passwords, but that feature is more reliant on Google (Android OS) and app makers/websites implementing it, but I want the hardware to already be there if/when they do!)
5. Dual Front Facing Speakers: They did it for the Moto G 2014 & the Nexus 6, why not for their own flagship?!? So stupid! Add it to the next Moto X or GTFO Motorola.
6a. Better OLED Screen: The Burn-in is real! Twist Sammy's arm to get the better version that they currently use on their Note 4 or find another vendor with less burn-in. 
P.S. I'm fine with 1080p as long as it saves on battery life.
6b. Larger 5.5" Screen: More screen, less bezels, please? 
7. Offer 128 GB Option: I know it's going to cost more but at least offer it as an option for the folks that want to drop the cash on it.
P.S. 16 GBs with no expandable storage is a bit of a joke, so you can even drop that as an option and go with 32, 64 & 128 GBs instead.

Paper-thin phones are so because you sacrifice battery life. With battery technology as it is today, you're no longer holding a brick in your hand. Today's batteries are less bulky because they're stretched longer and embedded as part of the hardware. This allows for not much sacrifice in capacity, as opposed to the standard swappable thick, square battery. Personally, I don't mind a little bulk as long as I know the battery will last me AT LEAST a day plus.

Fix the bug where it can't see or connect well to certain older phone repeaters / signal boosters.
Category 6 LTE with at least 4x4 MIMO and 64 QAM.
Removable battery. Motorola can sell 2nd / replacement batteries and more than 1 customized back to many customers.
Rubberized and deeply grooved / patterned back to reduce slips and drops.
Much stronger glass. Do Motorola's product designers have kids, or what?
Wireless charging. The female part of the USB plug is a weak spot, as well as those flanges on the male part.
Less than 4.5" screen at 720p. Improve the color and brightness rather than increasing size. This is a telephone, not a book reader. It has to fit comfortably in the pocket and hand. People who want higher res and bigger screens can cast screen or hotspot to a computer.
External micro-SD slot. I want to be able to carry around lots of videos of my kids, without otherwise impacting performance. Market it as the family-friendly phone, and let other companies have the tiny niche avant garde market.
Camera with 3-axis OIS.
Front-facing stereo speakers.
AM/FM radio.
Too sleepy to remember the others I've been thinking of.

title: 2015 Moto X !? Rumor Mill

thread.text:
The "New" New Moto X ? Hello Moto Lovers! I've Decided To Create This Thread For The Fans ... I'm Pretty Sure We All Know What's Coming This Fall, Something We've All Probably Anticipated. The 3rd Gen Moto X Of Course  ... I Couldn't Seem To Find Any Actual Articles About What The New Moto X Is Going To Be Bringing To The Game, So Lets Start Our Own Rumor Mill! Please Everyone Be As Realistic As Possible, That Way We Can Possible Assume What The New Moto X Is Packing. As For Me I Think The New Moto X Will: 
Feature A 5.2 - 5.5" Inch Screen With A Resolution Of 1440 x 2560, Pixel Density Ranging From 564.85 - 534.04 Pixels Per Inch, AMOLED Capacitive touchscreen 16M, Corning Gorilla Glass 4. A 2550 - 3100 mAh Battery (Non-removable) Quick Charge 2.0. A Qualcomm Snapdragon 810, Quad-core 2.1 GHz Cortex A-57 (64-bit), Adreno 430, 2.5GB Ram. A 16MP (2988 x 5312) Primary Camera With OIS, Dual-LED (Ring) Flash, Auto Focus,4k Capabilities. A 4MP Secondary Camera. 32/64GB With Expandable Memory Up To 128GB. Fingerprint Scanner (Moto Dimple). Dual Front Facing Speakers. Very Similar Design In Favor To The Nexus 6, 8.0 - 9.0 mm Thick. Aluminum Frame, Gold Option. More Back Skins ( Texture & Color) , Possible Truly Custom Backing Color. More Features In Moto Suite. Improvement In Low-light Picture Quality And Image Processing. With All That Said I Think The New Moto X Will Run Between $599 - $749 Off Contract.

It NEEDS to have a better camera. The camera is the only complaint I have about my 2014 Moto X. It's getting embarrassing how inconsistent and frustrating the camera is compared to the current crop of Apple, Samsung, LG, etc., offerings. I couldn't wait to upgrade from the 2013 to the 2014 X, but if the camera is no better in the 2015 model I might have to pass.
